The queen is parked like artillery on the h-file, but Black’s queen just stepped to b6 eyeing b2.  
I must keep the initiative, not retreat. The best way to parry the threat and accelerate the attack is to castle queenside myself, bringing the rook to d1 with deadly pressure on the d-file while simultaneously unraveling my king towards safety. A tactical finesse: if Qxb2 then after Rb1 the queen must abandon the long diagonal and the kingside collapses anyway.

The black king has no breathing room; its defenders are either tied down or shipped to the wrong wing, and every white piece is aimed at the kingside.

I now uncork the killing sequence: the dark-square bishop joins the assault with tempo by capturing on h7, ripping open the g-file for the still-unseen h-rook. Once the h-pawn is gone, the queen will slide in on the seventh rank with deadly checks that nothing can parry.

rounds.response:
White has an overwhelming position: the king is permanently stuck in the center, the rooks are immobile, and every black pawn is backward or under fire.  Now the simplest finish is to bring rational reinforcements into the attack—namely the h-rook—so that further sacrifices, discovered checks and mating nets simply flow.

A rook lift along the third rank will prepare deadly checks along the g-file, but first we evacuate the g-file so the queen can retreat into the kill-zone.

Therefore:  [h2h3]

The finishing idea is simple but murderous: fork the rook and h8–square at one stroke while clearing the g-file for a queen-rrook swat up the board.  
Time to drop the hammer:

[Dd1h1]

(That refiles the rook on the g-file with tempo, preparing Qg6+ or Qg8 mates, while also cutting off any remaining black defender escaping along the g-rook file)
